title: Can your boss make you get vaccinated in Australia?
description: Debate continues over whether workplaces should mandate vaccinations for their employees. In Australia, only a few companies have decided to make their workers get the jab – including Qantas. But questions have been raised about the legality and ethics of it all. Laura Murphy-Oates talks to political reporter Paul Karp about what mandatory vaccinations in workplaces would look like
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Paul Karp; produced by Karishma Luthria, Jane Lee, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning; sound design by Camilla Hannan; the executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson

title: How we all got hooked on caffeine
description: It’s the world’s most widely used psychoactive drug, it disrupts our sleep, it makes us grumpy when we miss it. What keeps us coming back?
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Michael Pollan; produced by Sami Kent and Courtney Yusuf; executive producer Archie Bland. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Gladys Berejiklian says the Covid rules are simple, but are they? – with Lenore Taylor
description: As Covid-19 cases in New South Wales hit record highs, the premier insists people understand the rules. But with different rules for different areas all across the state, is it really all that easy to understand? Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher speak to Gabrielle Jackson about confusing rules, mixed messaging and finding a clear way to communicate in a pandemic
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert and Camilla Hannan. Executive producer Miles Martignoni

title: Australia’s failure to vaccinate Indigenous people
description: Covid-19 is spreading throughout western NSW – even infiltrating small, remote Indigenous communities – in what is now the worst outbreak for the Aboriginal population in this pandemic so far. Meanwhile vaccination rates for Indigenous people are lagging behind the general population, with particularly low rates across western NSW.Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam explains how a series of failures at a state and federal level led to this moment, and outlines the need for transparency and accountability
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Lorena Allam; produced by Karishma Luthria, Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning; the executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Sydney’s suburbs hardest hit by Covid now at breaking point
description: The NSW government continues to enforce stricter lockdown measures in 12 local government areas at the centre of Sydney’s Delta outbreak. Operation Stay at Home, launched this week, increases police and ADF numbers and imposes larger fines of $5,000 for breaching public health orders. However, some residents question whether tougher enforcement is the answer.Laura Murphy-Oates speaks to reporter Mostafa Rachwani and NSW Labor MP Jihad Dib about policing, financial support and how this lockdown has left some residents on the verge of a breakdown
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oatesand reported by Mostafa Rachwani; produced by Karishma Luthria, Jane Leeand Joe Koning; mixed by Camilla Hannan; the executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jacksonand Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How the Taliban took Afghanistan
description: The departure of US forces was followed by a rout of Afghan government forces. Now, after 20 years of western intervention, Afghanistan is back under the control of the Taliban
contributors: Presented by Michael Safi with Emma Graham-Harrison; produced by Sami Kent and Axel Kacoutié; executive producers Phil Maynard and Archie Bland. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The ‘double standard’ behind Centrelink’s jobkeeper debt recovery
description: More than 11,000 jobkeeper recipients have received debt letters from the Australian government asking them to pay back welfare payments they received during the Covid pandemic. Meanwhile, the Coalition is resisting calls to claw back money from businesses that got the wage subsidy and then made a profit.Laura Murphy-Oates speaks to reporter Luke Henriques-Gomes about what some say is a ‘double standard’ at the heart of this debt-recovery effort, and jobkeeper recipient Hannah explains how – after living through multiple lockdowns in Melbourne – this debt could ‘financially ruin’ her
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Luke Henriques-Gomes; produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning, who also did the sound design; mixed by Camilla Hannan. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Israel’s shadow war with Iran
description: A spate of attacks on one of the world’s busiest shipping trade routes is part of an escalating tit-for-tat conflict playing out between Iran and Israel, says Martin Chulov, the Guardian’s Middle East correspondent
contributors: Presented by Nosheen Iqbal with Martin Chulov; produced by Sami Kent and Axel Kacoutié; executive producers Phil Maynard and Archie Bland; introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The science is clear on the climate crisis but is the PM? – with Lenore Taylor
description: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was unequivocal in its report this week: human activity is causing rapid, and potentially catastrophic, changes to the climate. Editor Lenore Taylor and head of news Mike Ticher unpick the climate rhetoric of prime minister Scott Morrison and his deputy Barnaby Joyce in response to the landmark report
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert and Karishma Luthria with sound design from Camilla Hannan. Executive produced by Miles Martignoni

title: The right to return home overseas
description: Australia’s tight borders have helped contain the spread of Covid-19. But now, Australians living overseas will have to apply for special permission to leave the country if they return temporarily, making it even harder for them to travel between the two countries they call home.Guardian reporter Elias Visontay explains how the new rules will affect Australian visitors
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Elias Visontay. Produced by Jane Lee, Karishma Luthria. Sound design by Camilla Hannan. Executive producers Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: ‘Code red’: the world’s climate wake-up call
description: A report by the IPCC – the world’s leading authority on climate science – has warned that climate change will probably cause global temperatures to rise by more than 1.5C, bringing widespread extreme weather. It also outlines how human activity is already changing the Earth’s climate in ‘unprecedented’ ways, with some of the changes now ‘irreversible’.Guardian Australia climate and environment editor Adam Morton breaks down the devastating global impacts outlined in this report, what lies ahead for Australia and the Pacific – and why we can still have hope
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Adam Morton; produced by Ellen Leabeater, Karishma Luthria and Joe Koning; the executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Should Australia vaccinate children against Covid-19?
description: The Delta variant has changed the way we think about Covid in children. Initially considered the last in line for a vaccine, some 12 to 15-year-olds are now eligible for Pfizer in Australia. But should we be vaccinating more young people? Science writer Donna Lu joins Laura Murphy-Oates to discuss what we know about how Covid-19 affects kids and whether they react differently to the vaccine than adults
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Donna Lu. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Karishma Luthria and Camilla Hannan. Sound design Camilla Hannan and Joe Koning. Executive producers Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: Why a Belarusian Olympic sprinter refused to fly home
description: Krystsina Tsimanouskaya flew out of Tokyo on Wednesday to begin a life in exile after refusing to return home. Andrew Roth describes a growing threat to internal critics of the Lukashenko regime
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Andrew Roth; produced by Joshua Kelly, Rudi Zygadlo and Elizabeth Cassin; executive producers Phil Maynard and Archie Bland; introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Sky News Australia, YouTube and misinformation in a pandemic – with Lenore Taylor
description: After Sky News Australia was restricted from uploading new content to YouTube for a week for violating the site’s medical misinformation policy, some of its commentators claimed the ban was another example of cancel culture, and a violation of their right to free speech.Gabrielle Jackson talks to editor Lenore Taylor and head of news Mike Ticher about the Sky News Australia business model and the complexities of regulating misinformation in a pandemic
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert and Camilla Hannan with Karishma Luthria. Executive producer Miles Martignoni

title: As Covid-19 hits aged care again, why aren’t more workers vaccinated?
description: A Covid-19 cluster in a Sydney aged care facility has highlighted the sluggish vaccination rollout for aged care workers, with recent figures showing only one in four are fully vaccinated. Many in the sector say the federal government’s plans to vaccinate workers have been confusing and beset by delays. But the government has put the onus back on staff – telling them to get at least one jab by mid-September or be barred from work.Reporter Christopher Knaus explores what went wrong with the rollout and the dangers of having a largely unvaccinated aged care workforce
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, reported by Christopher Knaus. Produced by Jane Lee and Karishma Luthria. Sound design by Joe Koning. Executive producers Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How to talk to family and friends about Covid-19 vaccinations
description: There are a number of reasons why your friends and family might be vaccine hesitant, so how do you approach a conversation to convince them? Medical editor Melissa Davey outlines the facts behind some of the common reasons for hesitancy and a health communications expert has some advice on how to approach this difficult discussion
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, reported by Melissa Davey and Michael Camit. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Karishma Luthria and Joe Koning. Sound design Camilla Hannan and Joe Koning. Executive producers Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The Afghans left behind in Australia’s longest war
description: After 20 years on the ground, Australian and allied forces have rapidly exited Afghanistan – ending Australia’s longest war. The Taliban has launched a nationwide offensive and violently acquired territory from the Afghan government, leaving local workers who once assisted the Australian defence force fearing for their lives. Laura Murphy-Oates speaks to Afghan interpreter Naser Ahmadi about how aiding Australian forces put him and his family in danger. Reporter Ben Doherty explores the situation in Afghanistan and why some Afghan workers have been left behind
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates; reported by Ben Doherty; produced by Jane Lee, Karishma Luthria Camilla Hannan  and Joe Koning. Executive producers: Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and  Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Donald Trump’s influence in Joe Biden’s America
description: It might seem like a post-Trump world, but in red states across the US his most hardline supporters are setting the political agenda. How much power do they have to shape the country’s future, even with a Democrat in the White House?
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with David Smith; produced by Courtney Yusuf and Dominic Fitzgerald; executive producers Archie Bland and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Are the NSW Covid disaster payments too little too late? – with Lenore Taylor
description: As the NSW Covid outbreak continues and millions of Australians struggle to access the financial support they need, the state and federal governments have announced increased Covid support payments. Guardian Australia editor Lenore Taylor and head of news Mike Ticher discuss if this expansion of financial support has hit the mark
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The ‘Witch of Darwin’
description: During the 1990s, Marie Cameron was known as the Witch of Darwin. It’s not a title she chose for herself but one she was given by the media, after a traditional Scandinavian bonfire, or ‘witch burning’, turned to violence. The events of that night would divide the community for years to come, with a media circus, a court battle, a protest, and the formation of a ‘council of witches’. Marie speaks to senior writer Brigid Delaney about how she became known as the Witch of Darwin, and the enduring symbolic power of the witch.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates   and reported by Brigid Delaney;  produced and sound designed by Joe Koning; mixed by Camilla Hannan; additional production by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert, Allison Chan , Jane Lee and Karishma Luthria; the executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson
